facts.text: Appellant was Sub-Inspector of Police and Station House Officer in-charge of Shehna police station in erstwhile PEPSU State.
Surjit Singh s/o Risaldar Waryam Singh arrested on September 25, 1953, at Barnala in PEPSU State by Police Inspector Jaswant Singh.
Surjit Singh kept in lock-up at Barnala and on following day (September 26, 1953) custody handed over to appellant and taken to Shehna police station lock-up.

Surjit Singh kept in custody at Shehna from September 26, 1953, till October 10, 1953, at about 10 p.m., when surreptitiously removed to Police Station Dialpur, then to Police Post Hamirgarh, and then to Police Station Baga Purana in Ferozepur District, Punjab.
Application under s.491 CrPC and Art.226 Constitution for writ of Habeas Corpus and Mandamus filed in PEPSU High Court alleging unlawful custody without charge or remand.

Appellant filed affidavit dated October 13, 1953, stating Surjit Singh had association with notorious dacoits, appellant never took him into custody, Surjit Singh was absconding and not arrested, not in appellant's custody, Inspector Jaswant Singh never entrusted custody to appellant, no petition or telegram received.

Affidavit affirmed: 'I solemnly affirm that the facts stated from paras Nos. 1 to 7 are true to the best of my knowledge and belief and nothing which is relevant to this case has been kept back from this Hon'ble Court'.
Both parties admitted before High Court that Surjit Singh not in appellant's custody; petition dismissed.
On November 9, 1953, brother of Surjit Singh made application under s.476 CrPC for prosecution of Inspector Jaswant Singh and appellant for perjury under s.193 IPC for false affidavits.
PEPSU High Court Judge ordered prosecution of appellant and directed Registrar to file complaint.
First Class Magistrate at Patiala took cognizance, convicted appellant under s.193 IPC, sentenced to nine months imprisonment and fine of Rs.300/-, in default two months SI.

Appellant's appeal to Sessions Judge, Patiala (Criminal Appeal No.175/36 of 1955-56) dismissed except sentence reduced to three months SI and fine Rs.50/-, in default one month SI (judgment dated February 22, 1956).
Revision to PEPSU High Court (Criminal Revision No.45 of 1956) dismissed in limine by Chief Justice with reasons (order dated March 7, 1956).
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant was legally bound to file an affidavit in the Habeas Corpus proceedings such that false statements therein attract liability under s.193 IPC read with s.191 IPC.
Whether Deputy Registrar of PEPSU High Court was authorised to administer oath for the affidavit.
Whether affidavit affirmed 'to the best of knowledge and belief' precludes conviction under s.193 IPC.
Whether Magistrate erred in procedure by not holding enquiry under ss.200 and 202 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant not bound to file affidavit as PEPSU High Court Rules for Habeas Corpus under s.491 CrPC and Art.226 do not require affidavit in return, unlike rules for other writs; thus case does not fall under s.191 IPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: PEPSU High Court Rules; s.191 IPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Deputy Registrar of PEPSU High Court not authorised to administer oaths.
Affidavit affirmed 'true to best of knowledge and belief'; unclear which parts to knowledge vs belief.
Magistrate erred by not holding enquiry under ss.200 and 202 CrPC as required under s.476(2) CrPC.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant was bound to file affidavit to justify detention when facts challenged in Habeas Corpus proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: In Habeas Corpus proceedings, when issues of fact raised and police actions challenged, affidavit necessary to justify custody; appellant bound to disclose facts by affidavit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of Habeas Corpus is expeditious, simple proceedings; affidavit needed when facts to enquire emerge.

court_reasoning.text: High Court and officers authorised under Oaths Act ss.4,5 to administer oaths; appellant giving evidence before court bound under s.14 to state truth.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.191 IPC applies whenever person on oath states falsely before court.

court_reasoning.text: Deputy Registrar stated he could administer oath; contention rejected.
Affidavit paragraphs affirm facts to appellant's knowledge; even belief covered by Expl.2 s.191 IPC; Emperor v. Lachmi Narain not good law as ignores Expl.2.
court_reasoning.key_observation: False statement as to belief within s.191.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.200 proviso (a) CrPC, no need to examine complainant when complaint by court; no preliminary enquiry under s.202 required before issuing process.

holdings.text: Appellant legally bound by oath to state truth in affidavit; false statements attract s.193 IPC.
Deputy Registrar authorised to administer oath.
'Best of knowledge and belief' does not preclude liability under Expl.2 s.191 IPC.
No enquiry required under ss.200,202 CrPC for court-filed complaint.

precedents_cited.relevance: Habeas Corpus proceedings should be expeditious, free from technicality; affidavit needed for fact enquiry.
No affidavit needed if detention under plenary discretion or court order.
Allahabad HC judgment on 'knowledge and belief' in affidavits; not good law, ignores Expl.2 s.191 IPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines giving false evidence on oath; applies to false affidavit in court proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Habeas Corpus petition; prosecution for perjury; no enquiry needed for court complaint.

statutes_cited.name: Oaths Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Authority to administer oaths; bound to state truth before court.

statutes_cited.name: PEPSU High Court Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for writs under Art.226 and s.491 CrPC.

outcome.summary: All contentions of appellant repelled; conviction under s.193 IPC and sentence as modified by Sessions Judge upheld.

key_quotes.text: "The whole object of proceedings for a writ of Habeas Corpus is to make them expeditious, to keep them as free from technicality as possible and to keep them as simple as possible."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains necessity of affidavit only when facts disputed.

key_quotes.text: "Whenever a man makes a statement in court on oath he is bound to state the truth and if he does not, he makes himself liable under the provisions of s.193."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on liability under s.193 IPC.

key_quotes.text: "A false statement as to the belief of the person attesting is within the meaning of this section..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
